definition: a doctor who studies and treats skin diseases
a belief that something will happen because it is likely
a hope that something good will happen
a strong belief about the way something should happen or how somebody should behave
to shine light on something
to make something clearer or easier to understand
to decorate a street, building, etc. with bright lights for a special occasion
to make a person’s face, etc. seem bright and excited
a doctor or scientist who is a specialist in the urinary system
a person who is an expert in mathematics
a person whose job or role is to kill people as a punishment, especially a public official who executes criminals
the structure of bones that supports the body of a person or an animal; a model of this structure
a very thin person or animal
the main structure that supports a building, etc.
the basic outline of a plan, piece of writing, etc. to which more details can be added later
the smallest number of people, etc. that you need to do something
a type of sledge (= a vehicle for sliding over ice) for racing, used by one person lying on their front with their feet pointing backwards
the sport or event of racing down a special track of ice on a skeleton (6)
something shocking, embarrassing, etc. that has happened to you or your family in the past that you want to keep secret
a chemical element. Neptunium is a radioactive metal.
the practice of killing somebody as a punishment by tying a rope around their neck and allowing them to drop from a high place; an occasion when this happens
a large piece of material that is hung on a wall or around a bed for decoration
a circle that is tied in one end of a rope, with a knot that allows the circle to get smaller as the other end of the rope is pulled, that can be used to kill somebody by hanging them by the neck
a doctor who studies and treats tumours in the body
a person or company that makes beer
an animal that has a female horse and a male donkey as parents, used especially for carrying loads
a person who is paid to take drugs illegally from one country to another
a slipper (= a soft shoe for wearing indoors) or a woman's shoe that is open around the heel
a set of rooms for living in, usually on one floor of a building
a set of rooms used for a holiday
a room in a house, especially a large or famous house
a form of chemistry studied in the Middle Ages that involved trying to discover how to change ordinary metals into gold
a mysterious power or magic that can change things
the act of forgiving somebody; the quality of being willing to forgive somebody
kind treatment of somebody when they are being punished; a lack of desire to punish somebody so severely
feeling or showing strong sexual desire
referring to or involving sex in a rude and offensive way
causing harm or damage deliberately and for no acceptable reason
behaving in a way that is thought to be immoral; thought to have many sexual partners
a small change made to something in order to correct or improve it
a change in the way a person behaves or thinks
to wash inside the vagina using a stream of water
an area of a country or city where the people have a different religion, culture or nationality from those who live in the country or city that surrounds it
a drink usually made from a mixture of one or more spirits (= strong alcoholic drinks) and fruit juice. It can also be made without alcohol.
a dish of small pieces of food, usually served cold
a mixture of different substances or elements, often ones that do not mix together well
a person who operates the controls of an aircraft, especially as a job
a person with special knowledge of a difficult area of water, for example, the entrance to a harbour, whose job is to guide ships through it
a single television programme that is made in order to find out whether people will like it and want to watch further programmes
a small flame that burns all the time, for example on a gas boiler, and lights a larger flame when the gas is turned on
a medical condition in which a person feels very sad, anxious and without hope and often has physical symptoms such as being unable to sleep, etc.
the state of feeling very sad and without hope
a period when there is little economic activity and many people are poor or without jobs
a part of a surface that is lower than the parts around it
a weather condition in which the pressure of the air becomes lower, often causing rain
to make something look bright, as if covered with gold
to cover something with a thin layer of gold or gold paint
to cause something to be less good or beautiful than it already is by trying to improve it
a large South American snake of the boa family, that wraps itself tightly around other animals to kill them before eating them
the activity of tricking people by getting them to give their identity, bank account numbers, etc. over the internet or by email, and then using these to steal money from them
an informal talk involving a small group of people or only two; the activity of talking in this way
the activity of going into the sea, a river, etc. to swim

a short set of keyboard symbols that represents the expression on somebody’s face, used in email, etc. to show the feelings of the person sending the message. For example :-) represents a smiling face (when you look at it with your head on one side).
smiling; cheerful
to move gradually through a surface that has very small holes or spaces in it
to gradually become known or spread through a group or society
to make coffee in a percolator; to be made in this way
the system of laws and basic principles that a state, a country or an organization is governed by
the condition of a person’s body and how healthy it is
the way something is formed or organized
the act of forming something
dealing with real, important or serious matters
a small device that is used with a computer, especially to access protected software or the internet
the fact of not getting punished for something
